docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In ''Cut and Run'' (Op-Ed, Jan. 28), describing the Caesarean section rates at major city hospitals (NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital/Columbia had the highest rate, North Central Bronx Hospital had the lowest), Tina Cassidy states, ''Even some midwives, the guardians of natural birth, have admitted to me that they can tell by looking at a pregnant woman's résumé whether she will be more prone to a Caesarean.''
docs.abstract: North Central Bronx Hospital midwifery director Susan Papera and Diane Lifton letters on January 28 article on Caesarean section rates at major New York City hospitals

headline.main: Requiring a Vaccine for Young Girls (5 Letters)
headline.print_headline: Requiring a Vaccine for Young Girls

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''A Vaccine to Save Women's Lives'' (editorial, Feb. 6): I disagree with your suggestion that other states besides Texas would be wise to require the vaccination against the human papillomavirus, or HPV infection, a sexually transmitted virus that causes cervical cancer.

headline.main: Requiring a Vaccine for Young Girls

docs.abstract: Letters from Amanda Styron, Alan Katz, Dr Deborah Kamali and Elizabeth Beiter oppose Feb 6 editorial praising Texas for becoming first state to require girls entering sixth grade to be vaccinated against sexually transmitted virus that causes cervical cancer; Sue Abercrombie says that government should not restrict its vaccinations to victims--it should include carriers

docs.lead_paragraph: Shavohnna Brisco, who completed a drug rehab program, has called the day she was busted for dealing drugs "the luckiest day of my life."

headline.main: After 2nd Arrest, Woman Finds a Life Free of Drugs
headline.print_headline: After 2nd Arrest, Woman Finds a Life Free of Drugs

docs.snippet: Shavohnna Brisco, who completed a drug rehab program, has called the day she was busted for dealing drugs "the luckiest day of my life."

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Who's out?'' said the voice in the darkness, slurring his words. He sounded slow-witted. ''Who's out?'' he cried, using street argot to plead for sellers of crack cocaine. Shavohnna Brisco, then a prostitute living in a traffic tunnel in the Bronx, recalled hearing the man's whimpers. She had some extra crack. ''My heart softened,'' she said. ''I didn't want anybody to take advantage of him.''

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; After 2nd Arrest, Woman Finds a Life Free of Drugs

docs.abstract: Shavohnna Brisco receives money for clothing for job interviews from Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, beneficiary agency of New York Times Neediest Cases Fund; photo (M)
